message.content:
topological space
manifold
homeomorphism
continuous function
open set
closed set
compact space
connected space
homotopy
topological invariant

Note: These terms are all closely related to the field of topology in mathematics. A topological space is a set endowed with a structure, called a topology, which allows defining continuous deformation of subspaces, and, more generally, all kinds of continuity. A manifold is a topological space that locally resembles Euclidean space. A homeomorphism is a continuous function between topological spaces that has a continuous inverse function. A continuous function is a function between topological spaces that preserves continuity. An open set is a set that is a neighborhood of all its points. A closed set is the complement of an open set. A compact space is a topological space in which every open cover has a finite subcover. A connected space is a topological space that cannot be represented as the union of two disjoint nonempty open sets. A homotopy is a continuous deformation between two continuous functions. A topological invariant is a property of a topological space that is preserved under homeomorphisms.
